question.title: Calling a method on the object returned by CrudRepository save() method
question.body:
I am trying to write a JUnit test for a relatively basic class that is responsible for persisting an object with a Spring Data CrudRepository, then extracting the generated ID from the object and using that ID as the input for some more logic. I have mocked my repository class and am using the standard when().thenReturn() to get the "saved" entity, but whenever I try to call the method to get the ID of the saved entity I get a NullPointerException telling me that the saved entity is null.

Here is the code I am trying to test:

@Service
public class OrderSchedulingService {
    private final OrderEventHistoryRepository orderEventHistoryRepository;
    private final ObjectMapper objectMapper = new ObjectMapper();
    private final CommonUtils commonUtils;

    public Integer processOrderScheduling(ConsumerRecord<String, String> consumerRecord) throws JsonProcessingException, NullPointerException {
        myMessage myMessage = objectMapper.readValue(consumerRecord.value(), MyMessage.class);

        Payload payload = myMessage.getPayload();
        String[] orderItemIds = payload.getOrderItemIds();

        for (String orderItemIdStr : orderItemIds) {
            Long orderItemId = Long.parseLong(orderItemIdStr);
            OrderEvent event = commonUtils.getOrderEvent(myMessage, orderItemId, OrderEventCode.ORDER_SCHEDULED);
            Long eventId = orderEventHistoryRepository.save(event).getEventId();
            
            //do some other stuff with eventId
        }
    }
}

Here is my test class:

public class OrderSchedulingServiceTests {

    @Mock
    private OrderEventHistoryRepository orderEventHistoryRepository;

    @Mock
    CommonUtils commonUtils;

    @Mock
    private ObjectMapper objectMapper;

    @InjectMocks
    private OrderSchedulingService orderSchedulingService;

    @BeforeEach
    void setUp() {
        MockitoAnnotations.openMocks(this);
    }

    @Test
    public void processOrderSchedulingSuccessTest() throws Exception {
        
        ConsumerRecord<String, String> consumerRecord = mock(ConsumerRecord.class);
        String messageValue = "{\"action\":\"SCHEDULE_ORDER\", \"payload\":{\"orderId\":\"12345\", \"orderItemIds\": [\"1\", \"2\", \"3\"]}}";
        MyMessage myMessage = mock(MyMessage.class);
        OrderEvent orderEvent = mock(OrderEvent.class);
        Long orderItemId = 1L;
        Long eventId = 67890L;

        when(consumerRecord.value()).thenReturn(messageValue);
        when(objectMapper.readValue(consumerRecord.value(), myMessage.class)).thenReturn(myMessage);

        when(commonUtils.getOrderEvent(omsMessage, orderItemId, OrderEventCode.ORDER_SCHEDULED)).thenReturn(orderEvent);
        
        when(any(OrderEvent.class).getEventId()).thenReturn(eventId);
        when(orderEventHistoryRepository.save(any(OrderEvent.class))).thenReturn(orderEvent);
        
        // This line gives me a NullPointerException
        when(orderEventHistoryRepository.save(orderEvent).getEventId()).thenReturn(eventId);
        
        //more test code here
        
        assertDoesNotThrow(() -> orderSchedulingService.processOrderScheduling(consumerRecord));
        verify(orderEventHistoryRepository, times(1)).save(any(OrderEvent.class));
        //other assertions
    }
    
    //Other Tests
}

What is the correct mechanism to get have the getEventId() call succeed here? Specifically this line: when(orderEventHistoryRepository.save(orderEvent).getEventId()).thenReturn(eventId);

answers.body:
@Mock
    private OrderEventHistoryRepository orderEventHistoryRepository;

Together with MockitoAnnotations.openMocks(this); creates and assigns a new Mockito mock instance. This instance doesn't do anything by default, unless you stub specific methods with Mockito.when(…).thenReturn(…) (or Mockito.doReturn(…).when(…)). Because non-void methods must return something, by default, Mockito will return a sensible default value (false for booleans, zero for numeric types, empty collections, and null for everything else including strings).

Now, when you call when(orderEventHistoryRepository.save(orderEvent).getEventId()).thenReturn(eventId);, Java needs to first call orderEventHistoryRepository.save(orderEvent), before it can invoke .getEventId() on the returned value. The return value of getEventId() is then passed to when – this is all regular Java and does not have anything to do with Mockito (yet).

Remember that Mockito mocks by default do not do anything useful and return default values. orderEventHistoryRepository.save(orderEvent) has not been stubbed, thus returns the default for the type – in this case null. You cannot call any method on null as this will result in a NullPointerException being thrown.

You need to stub the method to return a non-null instance. Usually, repositories return a value of the same type as the input parameter, so you could simply return its first argument:

when(orderEventHistoryRepository.save(orderEvent)).thenReturn(orderEvent);

Another possibility is to instruct your mock instance to return "deep mocks": instead of returning a sensible default value, each unstubbed method will return a new Mockito mock instance, which allows you to chain calls inside when:

@Mock(answer = Answers.RETURNS_DEEP_STUBS)
private OrderEventHistoryRepository orderEventHistoryRepository;

Additional notes:

  • when(any(OrderEvent.class).getEventId()).thenReturn(eventId); is guaranteed to always fail with a NPE. any(…) always returns null. You can only call when with method calls on a mock, you can not and must not use argument matchers standalone.

  • Depending on the interface size of your repository, you might be better off writing a simple, custom in-memory implementation of your interface

  • Your test is not verifying that your production code is actually saving the correct order. It simply verifies that any order has been saved.

  • I wouldn't replace ObjectMapper with a test double. Simply feed it valid JSON and you will get proper objects back (and not run into inconsistencies, because your double returns objects that do not match the JSON).

  • when(orderEventHistoryRepository.save(any(OrderEvent.class))) will only match non-null events. Make sure your other stubs are matching the calls and return a non-null order event.

And some recommendations from the official Mockito web site:

  • Do not mock types you don’t own (ObjectMapper)

  • Don’t mock value objects (e.g. MyMessage, OrderEvent)

  • Don’t mock everything (ObjectMapper)
